content:
Stop the presses! You have just about one week left to submit your responses to the Secure by Design RFI. Please make sure your voice is heard!

https://t.co/jTUsESgLRU https://t.co/eimuypVINn

You have about 30 days to submit your ideas on how to make software secure by design. Don't sit on the sidelines!

https://t.co/jTUsESgLRU

📢CISA released the second version of its Secure by Design whitepaper. https://t.co/hWdira3YVY 

Want to learn what’s new? Read on! #secureByDesign 🔐

Do you have some thoughts on how to improve the security of open source software? 
What?! You DO? Well, have I got an opportunity for you! 
(Note the deadline at the bottom)

https://t.co/5JV5VPPUHs

Have any of you Rust developers poked around these Windows kernel changes? I'd love to get some analysis. 

https://t.co/U6LnXONha7
Are there any good papers or presentations on how software companies measure the cost of CVEs in dollars?

What word would you use to describe the process of making an application hard to compromise? Examples include using memory safe languages and sandboxing. Is "hardening" acceptable? That term also has other meanings, but it seems the most appropriate. Help!

Aleph One's article "Smashing The Stack For Fun And Profit" appeared in Phrack on 1996-11-08. The 30th anniversary of that paper will be in 1142 days. 

What can we do between now and then to show him that we're finally taking the matter seriously? #memorySafety #secureByDesign

Sometimes the people with the best ideas don't speak up. Sometimes they speak up, but no one is listening. 

This open source security RFI is your opportunity to speak, and to be heard.🗣️📢

Do not sit on the sidelines!

(note the looming deadline!)
https://t.co/5JV5VPPUHs

@msuiche @CISAJen If you think funding would advance the cause, perhaps you'll consider replying to this RFI (note the looming deadline!):
https://t.co/5JV5VPPUHs
When ransomware initial access brokers break into a network, which product/technology is most often the first to be compromised, and how? (include data sources, please)
It’s entirely possible that well-funded security teams do not always result in well-defended organizations. 🤔

Sample questions reporters can ask software manufacturers after they release a CVE:
What class of coding errors were involved? (Memory safety? Input sanitation? Etc.) 
How long was it present?
What are you doing to eliminate this class of defect in the future? 
🔐 🤔
HTTPS deniers are a hoot.
Close calls are a goldmine of information for those brave enough to mine for it.

NIST is requesting feedback on SP 800-50 Rev. 1: "Building a Cybersecurity and Privacy Learning Program".
https://t.co/SRepBsuUBO
What examples of the "streetlight effect" have you seen recently in the security industry? https://t.co/XtloYkPc6j

Compare “authentication bypass vulnerability” and “authentication validation vulnerability”. 
Who is the implicit actor in each one?
Let me guess: Is it a memory safety vulnerability? 🐞 🔐

Just a regular reminder: SaaS vendors should mandate FIDO auth for staff to 100% of customer data, 100% of the time, with no legacy MFA fallback.

Orgs moved their data to cloud services, and those services must demonstrate their commitment to customer security. #SecureByDesign
SaaS vendors: Do you mandate FIDO authentication for all access to customer and other sensitive data? If not, what blockers are you running into?

The CISA #SecureByDesign whitepaper asks sw companies to take ownership of customer security outcomes. What does that look like in practice? 🤔
A recent example:
https://t.co/82tTg7UDIp
Chris Butera on a panel on secure by design engineering. 🔐 https://t.co/74u2MHNS3g

If you are at RSAC this week and have not yet mandated phishing-resistant FIDO authentication for your organization, please spend some time looking into it. Here's one place to learn more: 
https://t.co/kLbXEeb7mR

I'm honored to be speaking alongside many great folks!

📝 Today @CISAgov published a new site (https://t.co/hWdira3YVY), and launched a paper titled "Shifting the Balance of Cybersecurity Risk: Principles and Approaches for Security-by-Design and -Default".
See https://t.co/j5YjSfxb9F
#SecureByDesign

This may be the wrong time to bring it up, but in these desperate times, one @dickc quote may be just the thing to soothe an ailing nation:

"Extraordinary is taking a simple idea and revolutionizing it in a way that changes the world."

♥️

https://t.co/v8pVzQOtbF

Please stop using the passive voice.
You are making your good work hard for me to understand.
🙏
Have any tech vendors published a "Memory Safety Roadmap" that explains how they will eliminate memory unsafe code in their products over time?
I keep thinking about the breaches over the past couple of years, especially MFA bypasses, that only came to light because the attackers made their hacks known.
Are there any commercial VPN products (for enterprises) that nudge sysadmins and users to use MFA?
#Authenticate2022 Closing session. “Security by Community” is a great way to think about our efforts for the next few years. https://t.co/BhK3M7veDN

Arynn Crow and Sarah Cecchetti present on earning trust at scale 
#Authenticate2022 https://t.co/Pyy17TfXgu

.@pamelarosiedee about to present on navigating the ever evolving authentication landscape 
#Authenticate2022

Tina Srivastava talks about the great privacy challenge for reusable identity. 
#Authenticate2022 https://t.co/9Qlt42Z9q6

Rita Mounir and Chad Spensky talk about merging passwordless and physical access. 
#Authenticate2022 https://t.co/245arfVg3m

The term “phishing” can mean either “credential theft”, or “social engineering to trick a user into downloading and running malware” (or similar). Is there a shorthand term for the second type? We often talk past each other because of these differences. Input welcome!

Maliheh Shirvanian from Visa on proactive approaches to FIDO account recovery. 
#Authenticate2022 https://t.co/hPT4yZ9IUC
Jiphun Satapathy talks about implementing FIDO for a cloud and SaaS first enterprise. #Authenticate2022 https://t.co/9rNQXfK7Zc
The FIDO t-shirts are a hit! #Authenticate2022 https://t.co/XIjqk2i2YE
Darrell Hawkins from Otis Worldwide talking about authentication at scale. #Authenticate2022 https://t.co/KimN4r68xl

Yves Massard from HID speaks about the CTAP 2.1 standard in enterprises. 
#Authenticate2022 https://t.co/K5F0gzXnPJ

Marianne Crowe from Fed Reserve Bank of Boston talking about remote authentication fraud. 
#Authenticate2022 https://t.co/SA7j6T5jfi

Greg Cannon and @StephSchuckers talk about biometrics maturity. 
#Authenticate2022 https://t.co/hPonrI2io2

Great preso from @timcappalli on passkeys. Full house! Several good usability and accessibility questions. 
#Authenticate2022 https://t.co/KtcFmk8qvq
Roger Grimes explains MFA bypass attacks. #Authenticate2022 https://t.co/4OylG7IqsE
Phishing resistant MFA and the Exec Order talk by @dmennis. https://t.co/czlT3GJwoj
Ryan Galluzzo says NIST 800-63 updates are coming! Looking for information on the future of passkeys. #Authenticate2022
Eric Mill and Chris DeRusha in an OMB fireside chat with @jgrantindc. Bigger than life! Well done! #Authenticate2022 https://t.co/SP0AySivIe
Great talk by @0x636e68 about FIDO in use in different vertical markets. #Authenticate2022 https://t.co/ixfpYVxYCU

(Almost) 10 years of FIDO! 
Most “overnight success” bands have spent years perfecting their craft. This next year FIDO will be on everyone’s radar. 
#Authenticate2022 https://t.co/paZ95aZOmO
Here is @RachelTobac getting a shoutout at #authenticate2022 https://t.co/Fu0vq1bYR4
Can’t wait for the start of #Authenticate2022 to start! Come say hi if you see me! https://t.co/iGr831lhlK
Just started listening to the @ransomwarefiles podcast. Fascinating to hear first hand accounts from front line defenders who share details of attacks on their systems. Great stuff!
Excited to attend the @AuthenticateCon conference starting tomorrow. All FIDO all the time! 🔐
Which vendors are making the most progress implementing a "secure by design" philosophy? (memory safety, etc.) Examples and links to docs welcome!
What are your recent FIDO wins? Share even the small ones! 🔐

"How Cloudflare implemented hardware keys with FIDO2 and Zero Trust to prevent phishing"

If you want to know how one organization migrated to FIDO internally, check out this blog post. It's detailed, and easy to read. #moreThanAPassword 

https://t.co/kGVJdP6O4T https://t.co/xeuYwYz7gP

When you give security advice, ask yourself if you are teaching people how to survive using a product that is not #safeByDesign and #safeByDefault rather than pressuring the vendor to take ownership of the security outcomes of the customer.
Even in a crowded conference hall of several hundred people, the CO2 numbers are good. Impressive. https://t.co/iTE7yILVrk

Like @CISAJen says, security is a team sport. In this article, @MattT_Cyber spells out why. Bravo Matt! 

https://t.co/4LJypi8dR5
@MattT_Cyber @CISAJen It really captured the spirit of how we partner. I'll be sure to cite it frequently. Really awesome.

Twitter doesn't get enough credit for publishing these stats:
https://t.co/FNByjmraOn

What I like:
-Shows MFA usage
-Shows trend over time (though a line graph would help!)
-Shows breakdown of MFA types
-Regular updates

All online service providers should do the same. 🙏
Weren't we supposed to have microtransactions for things like website visits by now?
@CyberJarno Ah, so that's why! Thanks.

If you drive your car without using the seatbelt, the car will beep at you until you buckle up. It’s too dangerous, so the manufacturer nudges you to safety.
If you try to use most online services without MFA... nothing. No warning even though you are in danger. 

Why?

🧵Hardening guides are a roadmap of technology vendors deliberately and routinely deprioritizing the safety of their customers. 

Hardening guides can also be a roadmap for attackers, pinpointing unsafe features. 

We need products that are #safeByDesign and #safeByDefault.

"The internet was supposed to be the great equalizer… But it can never achieve that vision if security is itself unequal—if some users are more vulnerable to cybercriminals than others simply because they can’t see as well…"
https://t.co/EL9gKHEzM9

memory (un)safety

(are we still doing this??)
Imagine publishing a long and complicated hardening guide and thinking that your org has made security a priority for your customers.

There's a lot to unpack in this Canadian government report.
https://t.co/n3oKOKZ8F2
Like: https://t.co/itmWSk2qTf

All organizations should be as transparent as Cisco has been with this blog post about their intrusion. Full stop. This is what being responsible looks like. This is how you help other defenders. Thank you!

https://t.co/xPgdhH1BK1

Let me get this straight: The attackers sent convincing phishing messages, some employees FELL for the ruse and even then, the attack FAILED‽

What kind of MIRACLE product were they using?

<ASMR whisper>FIDO... 

https://t.co/tlY4agMH4x
What programming languages are most commonly used to write code for execution on satellites?

Fun fact: Abraham Lincoln was the first sitting US President to use a FIDO security key, and he was never successfully phished. 
It's your turn now! 🔑🔒🔐 https://t.co/XdPKe1ChDN

https://t.co/WmGAemFFhx 
“the single biggest attack vector for nation-states is stealing an identity, an authorized username and password set, and using it to exploit things”.

Then why doesn’t Amazon require MFA?

There are 2 types of MFA: 
1. Legacy (SMS, authenticator, push) that stop some attacks, but are still susceptible to phishing 
2. FIDO authentication, which is phishing resistant

MFA bypass attacks using phishing are on the rise. Migrate to FIDO authentication *this year*.

I was going through the Consumer Reports Security Planner again tonight. It's a fantastic resource for regular people who want to improve their security posture. Maybe you'll help someone go through it this weekend?
https://t.co/yOqxryBvoT

@ronnj18 @FIDOAlliance All true. While I will continue to ask the tech companies to make deployments simpler, I'll note that you can start your deployment in small waves. We completed the FIDO migration a few years ago at my last job. It is easier today than it was then.
I wonder what percentage of people seeing this message would do as the attackers say? https://t.co/MEAb2GZ8EO

Companies need to take ownership for the security outcomes of their customers. Example:
"Salesforce managed to convert approximately 80% of its monthly active users — about 14 million in total — to multi-factor authentication (MFA)"

https://t.co/gdC0WFJDNo

As you think about your backups from 30 days ago, are they actually backups? 

Or are they "Heisenberg backups"?

They are not backups until you test them, regularly.

What is this system?
"That's John's dev test box"
But it has access to production data.
"Um, I guess?"
Where is John?
He left last year.

#SecurityHorrorStories

ATTENTION! Break out your Enigma machines, radios, and Morse code tables!

Encrypted communications will commence at 2000Z (1300 Pacific) on 23 July on all KPH CW frequencies!

More details here:
https://t.co/HP91kmDIaP
Time flies! 🤯 #MyTwitterAnniversary https://t.co/1T7x11O5Tj

Time to take another look at the NY State Department of Financial Services stance on MFA! 🔑🔒
https://t.co/Hch2yBzSOo and
https://t.co/gWx8RnUTuf (December 7, 2021)
You should read that second document.
#MoreThanAPassword

"We require MFA for all remote access to our systems"

I have never been able to hide my micro-expressions when I hear/read that sentence.
Regular reminder that a common element in many compromises is a lack of MFA. https://t.co/0QG7RqcgWC

Looking forward to any comments from @LazyFishBarrel  about memory safety on this report! 🔑🔒🤔
  
https://t.co/pGdyqhMYnM

If Twitter ever creates an Edit feature, it should only be available to accounts protected by phishing-resistant FIDO security keys. 🔑 🔒 
Today only 2.5% of Twitter accounts use MFA. 
#MoreThanAPassword

I always push for FIDO keys for privileged accounts. People rightly observe possible speed bumps (perception of cost is the main one), and then we collectively give up.

Why do we let the problems of the last 10% block progress on the first 90%? Just start!🔒🔑
#MoreThanAPassword

This Twitter "Verified Account" help page says that the security requirement to qualify for a blue badge is that "Your account must have a confirmed email address or phone number".

Does Twitter not require verified accounts to use MFA?

https://t.co/dN6Fc7IV4T
Using FIDO security keys means never having to say you're sorry. 🔑🔒
Someone please crank up the air scrubbers at the Austin airport. CO2 levels much higher than SFO’s. https://t.co/dsA90VmJLf

SSO should not be priced as a luxury good like a yacht 🛥 . The SSO tax is a force that keeps organizations below the security poverty line. 
SSO should be free, and a customer right. 🔐 🔑  https://t.co/OGUYp3Al2r

This is a *brutal* SMB story. Some tactics that would have helped:
MFA (#MoreThanAPassword)
IRP (roles, comms, attorneys, LEA contacts, insurance)
Limiting on-prem services
Backup testing

Every SMB CEO should read this transcript *monthly*.

https://t.co/muzXFC6BTE

What is the copyright status of these #dallemini images? Who owns them? Can I use them? 
#MoreThanAPassword https://t.co/WfgQq86Ogr
How is you enterprise migration to FIDO? Any wins or speed bumps? Please share! 🔐🔑🙏🏻

Come see ⁦@DrHughThompson⁩ tell me more scary security stories like he did in 2029! 👻🔐

10:50 this morning, Moscone South Esplanade. 

Come early to get a good seat! https://t.co/dYuOK5OJxu

I am formally declaring @alex_gaynor's memory unsafety "stages of grief" video to be mandatory viewing by all security professionals.

If you are at @RSAConference, perhaps you'll find yourself talking to fellow attendees and even vendors about it.
🔑🔐
https://t.co/QU3ePPWxGT
Has anyone made a necklace for the Aranet4 CO2 meter?

"I tallied up all of the privacy policies just for the apps on my phone. It totaled nearly 1 million words. 'War and Peace' is about half as long."

https://t.co/5zwnXzJlOx

If I see you next week and ask if your org has started a FIDO authentication pilot/rollout, what will be your honest answer? 
🔑🔐

Vendors need to take ownership of the security outcomes of their customers. 

That looks like this: "Due to the power admins have to make changes to your environment, they’re required to perform MFA every time they sign in."
Bravo!🔐
cc @Alex_T_Weinert 

https://t.co/soUKp1iZq1
Are there any small businesses out there that would be willing to share their FIDO rollout successes?

Great talk by @alex_gaynor and @reaperhulk. Python! Cryptography! Rust! ASN.1! It’s all in there. 

https://t.co/KrPnJ49AZm

Someone needs to reshoot the SNL cowbell skit to be about MFA.
"Fellas. I coulda used a little more MFA..." 
"I'm telling ya! Fellas! You're going to want that MFA!"
"I got a fevah! And the only prescription! Is more MFA!"

Bonus points for including FIDO security keys. 
🔐🔐🔐
Should I? Is it dangerous? https://t.co/3HPAQsCVB7
@msager Thanks Mike! I'm looking forward to helping out where I can. 🔐

What techniques do you recommend for sending credentials securely to other people? I'm thinking of cases where you don't have an existing relationship with them, so no Signal, corporate password managers, etc. Here's one possible example:
https://t.co/magbittUgc
🔐🤔🧐❓

Reader’s Digest has explained 2FA (and FIDO!). Can we finally get every CEO and board to ask what % of their internal apps require it for staff to login? 🔑🔐🗝️🧐

https://t.co/mYLRGn6H0r

Where can I read up on what universities teach computer science students these days? I’m especially interested in programming languages, security concepts and tools. Stats and trends.

I assume I’m not even asking the right questions, so any insights would be much appreciated.
@chrisblizzard https://t.co/KTXTwTIwWh
@LannaMichalisko @mmurray Deepest condolences Lanna, and to Mike's family. Mike contributed greatly to our field and to many people, like me, on a personal level. We will all miss him greatly.
@msager Do you have this set? https://t.co/nunyy8Pm2X
@msager https://t.co/JAamtLEiup

It’s critical that consumers, enterprises protect themselves with MFA. But we don’t know if they do. Online services should publish monthly stats showing MFA usage broken down by:
- Consumer users
- Enterprise users
- Enterprise users with elevated privileges/sysadmins

Thoughts?

@chrismerkel We're on the same page. I suspect that increased transparency would yield a few things:
-Increased pressure from the services (can't be an admin without FIDO!)
-Awareness among execs that they are above/below average
-Evidence that regulators need to step in
@CindyOtis_ I'd be curious what would happen if you politely explain that you'd need funding. I've had success with that, but I've heard several other counter stories.
@jp4gs @chetdorn Not enough references to FIDO. 🔐

You know I love the DNC Security Checklist (https://t.co/SDrXMoMdzQ) which focuses on device and account security basics.

I also want to give a shout-out to the @ConsumerReports Security Planner which covers more ground in a thoughtful manner. It's great!
https://t.co/yOqxryBvoT

"The court orders allowed the F.B.I. to go into domestic corporate networks and remove the malware, sometimes without the company’s knowledge."

Are any of them publicly traded companies?

Will we get details so we can protect our networks, too?

https://t.co/CtCKtC1wIt

The WSJ published an article by @nicnguyen about security keys here:
https://t.co/gOkDzaUtqu

Some thoughts… 🧵

.@mononcqc's talk at #IRConf is great. It's called "Errors are constructed, not discovered". 

Fred, I hope you publish a reading list so we can catch up with you! 🙏
DuoLingo, but for cybersecurity concepts.

What impresses me about FIDO security keys isn’t the technology, despite the use of cool cryptography. What impresses me most is that it’s supported by modern browsers, phones, dozens of major online services (like Twitter!), and that there are multiple manufacturers of hardware.

Which cybersecurity vendors have migrated all staff logins to FIDO authentication so they won't get phished? Have there been any announcements or conference talks?
(If you approve vendor contracts, you should ask!)

This documentary about Elizebeth Smith Friedman is amazing. 

https://t.co/WcwdBhyjci

In light of recent events, I’ve been thinking about account and MFA lifecycles. I’ve been thinking about different preventive and detective controls, and also the differences between administrative (process) and technical controls. Some questions for orgs… 🧵

@lukasbradley Fair points! And to be clear, some teams need help with some business process reengineering. New tools. New vendors. Training. New workflows. And of course we are all human and resist change. I need to learn more about the various cloud-based IDEs. Maybe you can teach us! 😀

@lukasbradley Some of us have been successful in getting people to make the migration. We also found it much easier and cheaper for IT to support them. It's worth keeping an open mind and looking for places where you might be able to help people evolve their workflow and tools. Good luck! 🍀

@lukasbradley You get a few things in a Chromebook that you don't necessarily get in other Linux-based systems out of the box, like verified boot, and encrypted storage. I've also liked the "context aware" feature of Workspace that enforces policies on the devices.

In case I forgot to mention it before, you can eliminate _massive_ amounts of attack surface by moving staff to Chromebooks and mandating FIDO security keys. 
💻🔐

Defenders have very little technical visibility into attacks on other companies. In light of the Okta incident, it would be incredibly helpful to all learn more. I'm hoping the great people at Okta will share *all* the technical details. Some initial questions com to mind 🧵...
Congratulations to everyone who got FIDO security keys deployed! https://t.co/5EX7uUl63d

This is a good guide. If every CEO read it and personally took action, we'd be in a _much_ different place.

I especially like the link to a draft IRP. Starting an IRP is the hardest part. I'd only add that it needs formal sign off from sr execs.

https://t.co/ptmGVZ7IpY
I see security recommendations like “Ensure users create strong passwords”. OK, but what is a “strong” password?

"Last year, we showed that more than 70% of our severe security bugs are memory safety problems"

"...we’ll be exploring whether we can use a memory safe language for parts of Chrome in the future"

https://t.co/rStlIrYEKI

Sometimes when I hear security advice I wonder who the intended audience is. My non-technical friends? Big companies? Spies?

Most US companies are small. (2018 data below. The slices for the larger companies are razor thin.) https://t.co/FXYBKNA6jy
@adamcaudill @1Password Many thanks!!
I’m halfway through the documentary “Icarus” by @bryanfogel and it’s even more surprising and unsettling than I expected.

I know I'm the "OMG enable 2FA right meow (esp FIDO)!" guy, but…
I spent a good chunk of today trying to help a friend enable 2FA on his Facebook account.
Services need to invest more in security UI/UX, esp around SMS 2FA. It's not just Facebook.

A friend asked me recently why I push FIDO security keys so hard. Should orgs really delay other important work to get FIDO keys rolled out to their staff? Yes!
A thread… 🧵
If your org allows users to have admin rights on their laptops, is that a risk that the CEO and the board know about? (If not, why not?) 🙏

The advice in this article includes "back up important computer files" and "avoid 'suspicious' links" (whatever that means). No MFA‽🤔
https://t.co/QBGHXGLPR6

What a missed opportunity to teach people about real security basics, like these:
https://t.co/SDrXMoMdzQ

BEC scams are highly lucrative. Yet many (most?) could be stopped if payment systems implemented technical controls to limit who can add/change vendors & routing numbers.
Question: Which banks/payment systems implement these controls to eliminate BEC for their customers?
Chromebook users: Have you used an Apple keyboard and gotten the top row of function keys to work (full page, show windows, screenshot chords, etc.)?
Security is hard. 🔐 https://t.co/4WS5qirkWc
Twitter served me this ad. I may be hard to reach for a few days while I do some research (after I buy a CD player). https://t.co/yBHoL7HTra

I wonder what would happen if every cybersecurity expert going on TV this week said something like "Every CEO/board should ask what % of their staff are enrolled in MFA, and they should not be satisfied with any number other than 100%".

@m33x @Alex_T_Weinert What would the world look like if 100% of admins were enrolled in MFA (which MS could mandate)? For things like this it's normal to measure _progress_, but for critical security practices, I only look at the cold hard _outcomes_.

"The jump is due in part to cyber thieves finding a way around the increased security of multifactor authentication protections that rely on a text message or code sent to a customer’s phone to confirm their identity."
https://t.co/anw8dF8URV

Conference talk idea: We migrated from legacy MFA to FIDO security keys, with no fallback, for 100% of our users. Learn how we changed procedures ranging from training, to enrollment, to account recovery, to offboarding to _eliminate_ credential theft in our org.

@daviddpd @jessysaurusrex @Google @Atlassian @SlackHQ @github @Apple @1Password This can indeed be a big problem. Imagine if every neighborhood had its own standards for road signs and lane markings. Driving across town would be quite stressful and dangerous.

This NSA password guidance recommends password complexity (numbers, special chars). 
Any ideas why, given 800-63B? Did I misread?
https://t.co/n3zDfg4b0l

There are so many people doing amazing work to address the most _critical_ security problems we face today. Please don't discount your efforts. Submit talks! You'll get rejected a lot. Refine, and submit to another conference! 
Or, and I know this is crazy, just post on Youtube!
Conference talk idea: We moved our developers to  a cloud-based IDE and Chromebooks, dramatically increasing security of the code, and reducing the effort of trying to secure and manage laptops.
Conference talk idea: We moved from C++ to a memory safe language. Learn what we did right, and what gotchas we ran into.

Free research/conference talk idea:
Take the @CISAgov Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog and analyze the vulns against different vulnerability types, specifically memory unsafety. Are there trends that could help defenders and vendors?

We have warned users to not click on "suspicious" links for years. The idea is that a single click can compromise your machine.

In 2022 what are the actual risks to clicking on links? Exclude 0days & phishing. I’m only interested in that first click. Be super technical! 🙏
@SecurityAmar Yes, we have both more secure products, and more data about how attacks work. We should adjust our guidance appropriately.

Humble request to security pros: When a reporter calls to ask you for a quote about the security risks to users of <random thing that is not a risk>, please reframe to get the _real_ messages out there.

In 2007 I wrote: "Adding [a SecureID] device will protect the early adopters.  But as soon as a large percentage of customers use this device, the phishers will take it into account"

Bypassing legacy MFA has always been possible.

https://t.co/ASk4Utvsxn

Most people have very little appetite for changing their behaviors to be more secure. So it's important to think deeply about how we give security advice. I wrote this doc to summarize my thinking. Feedback welcome!
https://t.co/Sz7NXMNcPN

@wompdev @_mwc People have a very limited appetite for behavior change to be more secure. We need to prioritize and focus people on the top 2-3 things to be more secure. Lack of MFA leads to account compromises every second, not scanning QR codes. 
My suggestion: https://t.co/SDrXMoMdzQ
I didn't see the commercial, but why in 2022 do people think QR codes are any worse than visiting a new site? You do that daily, right?
If you think that was a Schitt's Creek commercial, you need to learn about SCTV.

Now that we had a commercial for QR codes, I'm looking forward to seeing some promoting free wi-fi and free USB charging stations!

#hacklore
@msager Every time you do an internet search you are visiting a site you don't trust. We put our trust in the browsers. Most of the time, that trust is justified.
@msager Is it any worse than visiting a new URL? If you're patched, you should be ok. Yes? No?

@BigPipPinching Correlation and causation are easy to confuse when there is only one data point for sure. In this case, how did they rule out a compromise of the vendor's CC system, for example? Unless the site's HTTPS configs were poor, the theft wasn't over the network.

@piescott04 5 years was arbitrary. Sorry about that!
There has been gradual progress since 2010 (look up "Firesheep"). There have been improvements in OSs, browsers, CAs, websites, TLS, Google down-ranks non-HTTPS sites (punishing the holdouts), etc.

@BigPipPinching What information, exactly? What web sites did they visit? Were they using other (possibly less secure) apps? How did they eliminate other common attack vectors (like password reuse, lack of MFA, phishing)? How did they isolate the time of compromise to the use of wifi? etc

Companies need to take ownership of their customers' security outcomes.

In case you are wondering why I'm obsessed with deploying FIDO security keys, here's the summary:
1 Many attacks start with phishing
2 No matter how much training we get, we are *all* going to fall for a phishing attack
3 When we do what the attacker says, FIDO thwarts the attack

"...the rate at which Yahoo employees’ credentials were captured in phishing simulations had been cut in half. The number of accurately reported phishing attempts had doubled. And most importantly, the usage of the company’s corporate password manager... had tripled."
🤯

In case I forgot to mention it here before, there are two types of MFA: (1) FIDO security keys, and (2) Legacy MFA that you need to replace with FIDO security keys.

At some point in time, not of your choosing, that may become very clear to your org.
